Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Near-infrared Emitting Lanthanide Complexes and Their Metallopolymers
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Hongshan He of Eastern Illinois University to develop new chemical compounds for bio-imaging and sensing. These compounds can be used to label tissues or other target structures, and after being activated by a light source, emit light, enablingimaging. Professor He's approach is to develop compounds that (i) do not need to be activated by ultraviolet light as such high energy radiation can damage biological tissues, and (ii) emit light at characteristic wavelengths that are not present in background emissions associated with biological systems. The project aims to provide opportunities for undergraduates to participate in research and gain hands-on research experience. The participation of high school students and science teachers in summer workshops is designed to stimulate student interest in pursuing studies in STEM fields.

Fluorescent materials are used for a variety of biomedical diagnostic applications, such as immunoassays. The significant overlap of biological substrate autofluorescence and fluorescence from commercially available probes dramatically compromises detection sensitivity. This project is aimed to address fundamental questions and such technical issues by developing rationally designed near-infrared emitting lanthanide materials through synthesis, computation, and photophysical studies. The project is focusing on BODIPY-based chromophores and aims to address a long-standing corollary concern of poor near-infrared emission of lanthanide materials in aqueous solutions. To meet the challenge, the lanthanide complexes are to be transformed to metallopolymers through carbon-carbon coupling reactions to suppress quenching and enable efficient near-infrared emission to be retained. The metallopolymers being targeted are designed to emit in the near-infrared region of the spectrum (900-1600 nm) under longer excitation wavelengths,thereby reducing autofluorescence and photobleaching.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is an increasing demand for advanced materials that can be used for sensing, imaging, and optoelectronic application. However, there are several barriers to the sensitive and accurate detection of many biological substrates and one of them is the lack of near-infrared emitting fluorescent materials for labeling during the detection. With support from the Nation Science Foundation, undergraduate students, graduate students and the PI from Eastern Illinois University studied a new class of materials and discovered some promising materials for biosensing and imaging. The major outcomes from this grant include the following:


 (1)    A series of organic chromophores abbreviated as BODIPYs that are widely used in bioimaging were found to be able to sensitize the near-infrared emission of ytterbium ion, one of the fifteen lanthanide ions on the Periodic Table. In combination with bio-relevant porphyrin chromophores, strong near-infrared emission was obtained upon illumination of red light.    


 (2)    Students received opportunities to gain hands-on research experience as well as knowledge in chemistry and photophysics. Fifteen undergraduate students and five graduate students participated in this program. They have been exposed to many aspects of chemistry including handling of air-sensitive materials, purification of complicated mixtures, and interpretation of spectroscopic data. Five students are currently pursuing a higher degree in other institutions. All students had opportunities to present their results in national, regional and local meetings with six students at the American Chemical Society national meetings and one for an oral presentation.  


(3)    Local high and middle school students participated in summer activities to inspire their interests in chemical science. The local Boys Scouts spent time in the PI?s laboratory, learned how organic molecules are formed using molecular models and how to obtain limonene from oranges using simple chemical extraction techniques. High school students attended week-long ?Chem Is Try? camp and they not only learned fundamentals of chemistry but also received hands-on experience in making copper from copper oxide and determination of oxygen percentage in the air by running some chemical reactions.


(4)    Research results have been published in peer-reviewed journals.  Six articles have been published with three under preparation.  Ten abstracts from the American Chemical Society national meetings were published.
